Content: Schafer: Hi, guys. How's it going?
This is the last one of these we'll ever do?
Offscreen: Yeah.
Schafer: Seems like only yesterday I was saying all that stuff, sitting in this chair
that I can't remember now, 'cause it's been so long ago.
Offscreen: Mm-hmm, we talked about that initial budget in that chair.
Schafer: Don't bring that up.
[Laughter] Yeah, it's just-- it's this one,
and then it's, ahh!
[Music] Schafer: Tonight, we are going to have a bonfire down at the beach
to celebrate the completion of "Broken Age," everybody.
[Applause] Yay!
Teamwork!
It started out like a really fun idea, and then it got really hard.
And a bunch of people wussed out, but a lot of people stuck around to the end.
I wanna thank you, thank you to the whole team, and thank you everybody.
We're done!
Like, we went to the beach, we had that party, things got a little out of control.
[Yelling] And it's fun, it's fun 'cause it's, like,
not fixing things right at the last minute.
We kinda had it done in advance a little bit, at least for-- for me and us.
Like, it was, um, wrapped and submitted.
Like, we had to submit for the disc version, and that kind of actually-- it was tough,
but it forced us to have a lot of stuff done before the, um, actual launch date,
'cause we had to have that version burnt to disc.
And so, um...we had to time to kind of, like...
adjust to the thought of it being over.
Um, so, Reds is done and it's awesome.
The end.
Rice: It's done?
Oh my God.
That's kinda sad.
We sent review keys out to press for "Broken Age," so there's already, like, 10 or so folks
that are playing for review.
With the amount of time that it's taken and the amount of things that have happened
in the last three years is, uh, staggering.
And, um, it was nice to see everyone care enough to push for a final product
that could be something we're proud of.
Crook: Um, so yeah, it just, um, it kind of all came together at the end.
Um...so I feel good right now.
Offscreen: You feel good about it? Crook: Yeah.
I think it's beautiful, and something that we should be proud of.
Uh, I think people are gonna really like it.
Russell: Yes, we're finished.
See, I knew it would happen.
And after 13, 14 years here, you know stuff's gonna get done,
and it'll be great in the end.
It'll be all worth it.
Schafer: Rusty. Russell: I'm playin' through and fixin' bugs.
Schafer: Well, thanks for playing.
Russell: Mostly playing. Schafer: Mm-hmm.
Awesome. What do you think so far?
Russell: I got confused, actually.
As much as I played through-- -I was-- Schafer: That's not good!
Rice: It's not a scripted cutscene, so you wouldn't know.
Russell: Yeah, exactly.
Schafer: Excellent, did you figure it out, or did ask for a hint?
Russell: I had to ask Ray.
Schafer: Oh... -Oh...
And also, look, it's running on, uh, iPhone 6.
-Thanks... Rice: Not anymore.
Schafer: Not--b-but--it's a black screen.
Oliver!
Oh, spoilers for "Act 2"!
Okay.
Anyway, it's running.
Franzke: But, yeah.
As you can see, the game is running a little thing-- This one just crashed, but it does work.
I am extremely proud of, you know, the product the way it is right now.
Um...and, yeah, I hope it will stand the test of time.
Schafer: And then we are on the street on April 28th.
It'll be awesome.
Um, and Anna's alive.
Look at that, everybody.
Yay, Anna's alive!
Yay!
Kipnis: It feels--it feels good.
It feels like, uh, we did-- we did something good and worthwhile
and something that hopefully will, you know, uh, have a-- I don't know, a future?
Like, have a legacy of some kind.
Schafer: I really, uh, felt good about the second chapter.
You know, I feel like it answered anyone's critique about the first one,
you know, without changing the game completely, you know.
I think it definitely was, you know, harder and longer, and, um, and amazingly done in less time, so...
Stoddard: I did my first full, full playthrough last weekend, and it is a hard game.
It's really challenging and it's really well-done and it's engaging.
Like, I've worked on this thing for years and I still-- like, the story was still getting me.
It's pretty good.
And when I hit the final scene, like, man, dude,
it's, uh... it's cinematic.
It's like it hits you.
Definitely.
Um...so that felt good.
I just had to have a moment to...
start loving it again.
I mean, like, I had this point in here where, like, the love I have for this just kinda
got knocked out for a few days.
And that was really scary.
That was really scary.
And, um...
It was hard.
Schafer: We're going to our last stand-ups?
Is it last stand-ups?
I believe it is.
Hello, everybody.
Oh, look at the big-- Did we not get bagels for the final stand-ups?
Crook: Ah, I didn't try.
Schafer: Come on! It's our last one.
Get your ass off Bagel.
I brought this for emotional support.
In case I get emotional.
Crook: Just keep hugging it. Schafer: I'm not gonna get emotional.
Crook: Squeezing it, hugging it. Schafer: I doubt it.
I doubt it. We're not done.
Are we? We done?
Crook: This is the last standup.
Schafer: You playing right now?
This game is so addictive.
Cannot put it down for one second.
Um...this might be-- this is our last proper standup for the full team, but, uh...
don't worry, I won't give a speech or anything.
And then you always have this post-project depression, which is, like, you've defined yourself by who you are
by making this game for so long, and then it's over and you're like, "Who am I?
Am I not the person who makes 'Broken Age'?
What am I? What's the point of it all?" Crook: Before, when we were just doing, like, a big game,
it would ship, and then the whole studio didn't have anything to do for a while.
And every--I think every-- the whole-- You could kinda feel that in the air
and it just kind of-- it was just-- it was kind of a downer.
And, uh, because there's multiple projects now, we can all just jump onto things,
and that helps-- helps you, uh, I think helps me, get out of that.
And so that's why there was a need on "Day of the Tentacle."
Um, so now-- now I'm on to that.
Um, I'm--I hear it's really bad for people who are leading the project.
Uh, but Tim doesn't-- I mean, he doesn't show it.
He's pretty good with hiding, I think, his sadness.
But, um...
He's just sad all the time.
No.
Uh, but I'm sure he-- I'm sure it will hit him, you know,
because this is three years, uh, put into this.
Schafer: No, I don't get depressed.
I'm too old to get depressed.
Offscreen: Don't you have any sympathy for all the people that have been insisting the game will never finish?
Schafer: I do--I do feel bad for all the people who have based their identity
on the fact that I'll never finish this game.
'Cause we'll finish it and then they'll have post-project depression.
If I'm not that person who hates Tim Schafer, who am I?
Excellent.
Thank you. Panya's last standup, for sure.
Inversin: Yeah, for sure.
I'm out this week, guys, so it's been a pleasure.
But, uh, uh, yeah.
Crook: Go inside, Victor. You're next.
Schafer: Yeah, nice try, Victor. Crook: There you go.
Romero: Almost. -Schafer: All right, we'll miss you, Panya. Victor!
Crook: Yep. Schafer: Victor.
Romero: I'll miss you, Panya, uh...
Schafer: Oh, shipping games is always tense, and then afterwards there's this moment
where if there's ever gonna be any turnaround in the company,
it usually happens at that moment, 'cause people hang on to the--they want--
everyone wants to finish the project they're on.
That--so that's usually the period where people will come and go,
is--is in that period.
Okay, everyone, thanks for coming to dailies all those times.
It's over. Next project.
Rice: Yay! Crook: That's it.
Stoddard: Man, he's sentimental.
Crook: Yeah.
Coull: So.
Sad panda- I'm leaving.
Um...
What else do you want to know about it.
No, I mean, um, the contract was supposed to come to an end anyway.
The fact that it went on a month after was pretty-- pretty awesome for me.
You know, maybe they'll need me again in the future, but, you know, you can't be certain, I guess.
Schafer: Oliver is still cranking away on the final final versions of it
to get it out the door.
And then Oliver will be moving back to Germany, sadly.
I think some of you know this; we've talked about this.
Oliver is--the-- the--the pull of the fatherland is too strong.
He must go back.
Oliver wants to move.
He's gonna keep working for us, but he's gonna move to Germany.
But he's gonna be working on "Day of the Tentacle." So you don't have to be mean to Oliver.
That's the main point. Usually when someone's leaving, we make sure everyone knows in advance
so that they can be mean to them.
Franzke: So in a few weeks, I'm actually going to move back.
So it will be interesting to see how...
how much German culture has changed since I moved away.
Maybe I'll feel like a complete foreigner for a while.
Who knows? I don't even know.
So, all future interviews will have to be through Skype.
Offscreen: Gonna miss you, Oliver. Franzke: Yeah...
I'm gonna miss you guys too.
It's gonna be weird.
Schafer: I think it's-- it's been a tough time because we haven't, you know,
it's been a while since we've given raises to people, and so there's other companies in the area
that are making a lot of money right now, and so they're able to throw that kind of money around,
and that'll probably cause us to-- Uh, that always happens.
We lose through--when, like, Oculus and Facebook took off, they started throwing money around.
We lost some people to that.
Um, but after "Broken Age" comes out, we'll be able to throw money around, right,
'cause we'll be rich off of, uh, all those point-and-click adventure dollars.
Actually, we don't expect to make a lot of money off of "Broken Age,"
because everyone bought it the first time.
And, um, but the new platforms like, um, PS4 are going to be opening up some new customers.
Bailey: There's a lot banking on it, but--but not everything.
I mean, we diversified to do some of those LucasArts properties
like "Grim Fandango" and, like, uh, "Day of the Tentacle." Uh, so "Grim" sales are really good.
Um, you know...
[Applause] It's, like, $1.7 million gross,
which is good.
So, across all platforms for the last week, um...
Schafer: I'm feelin' kinda gross. Bailey: Yeah.
And, you know, it looks like those are-- are gonna bring in a lot of, uh,
a lot of money for the studio, so...
Schafer: And I hope there's a lot of people out there who were just waiting for the whole thing to be one game
and don't care about crowdfunding and they don't wanna know about
our little transparency efforts.
They just wanna play a game when it's done and, um, hopefully they will buy it.
Please join me in welcoming Mr. James Spafford.
-Yay! -Thank you, guys.
James Spafford.
Uh, would you please stand up so everyone can see you.
This is James, and rotate one time.
No, you don't have to rotate.
Uh, James...
uh, welcome to Double Fine.
So James Spafford used to be one of the two people who ran Mixnmojo, which is an old LucasArts fan site,
and I knew him back then when he visited our offices in 2001, I think, and gave me some Marmite.
And, um...and now I said, "In 10 years, we'll hire you."
Fifteen years? "In 15 years, we'll hire you"-- as our community manager.
-Whoa. -He's not the new Chris Remo.
He will never be the new Chris Remo!
-Yeah. Muir: 'Cause he's not dead.
Schafer: In other news, Chris Remo's dead.
No.
Spafford: I mean, I'm a long-time follower of Double Fine and everything they've been doing.
I'm a backer.
Uh, obviously backed immediately.
Um, followed the documentary series, which I'm now on, which is really weird, uh...
Offscreen: Is he aware of everything that's happened?
Did he know what he was getting himself into?
Schafer: Don't tell him about gamergate.
No, he knows, he knows.
That's--that's the exciting new challenge for him, will be, um, rebuilding all the things.
Spafford: I knew what was going on.
I mean, certainly, lots of people were not happy about the game being split.
Um...so I feel like, yeah, that--that might've been the start of some troubles.
But probably the start of any community troubles was the day that the Kickstarter was made
and, um, $3.5 million was raised and a lot of people's money
was riding on a thing that they had in their head, a vision that they had that this thing was gonna be.
And, you know, it wasn't the way some people wanted it to be.
I never want to give up on people who are like, "You know, I'll try everything."
If people are really mad, a lot of the time you can--
you can--you know, you can bring them around.
There's always some way that you can make them happy again.
Um...yeah, it's just finding out what that is.
Schafer: It's--it's good timing, 'cause we're--as we're wrapping up the game, we're coming out of production
and getting back into all the community-facing stuff, like getting out the last of the backer rewards.
Like, we still have a lot of these little mini portraits that Bagel has to paint.
So, like, it's come to that point where we're kind of, um,
closin' the loop on the story, big story, and so we'll be facin' the backers a lot,
and it's good to have a community manager for that.
Okay, so we're just--are we just talking about the launch plans for the game as far as PR and marketing?
What's--what's your marketing budget on the game?
Rice: Zero...?
Schafer: Okay.
Spafford: One of the big things I wanna talk about is how we talk about "Act 2"
and how we properly do this, like how we bring this thing out.
Schafer: How do we talk about "Act 2"? Spafford: The biggest thing, right.
Schafer: So just, like, the--what's it called?
Spafford: Well, like, no, as in...
how are you getting people to think about it?
You want people to think about it as a whole game, -or as episode two? Rice: Yeah.
Schafer: Like, now that it's done, I would like it to just be just "Broken Age,"
as if we never split it at all.
Rice: So, yeah, I think that the hope was, like, a year from now, the story would be more about just the game as it is,
not that it was split or anything.
Spafford: When it was released, we did-- people did reviews of it and stuff, right?
Like, treated it like it was its own thing.
So I wonder how persuadable people will be to just forget that and move on.
Rice: But I still think we probably have to speak to the people who did already buy it, and--
Schafer: Yeah, because this is a worry that I do have, that people are like, "When's 'Act 2' coming out?"
And that they don't see that announcement, -"'Act 2' is out"-- Rice: Yeah.
Schafer: Like, the answer to that question, they might miss the fact that it came out.
Rice: Yeah.
Yeah, so I think we still need to be saying that, like, for people who purchased "Act 1,"
they're getting the full game now, updated with "Act 2" content.
Spafford: Yep. Rice: But...
Spafford: The PS4 and iOS is definitely a really good chance to just talk about the whole game.
So we've been trying to get people to play the PS4 version,
which is a new platform, um, and doesn't have that distinction.
Like, it's just one game on that platform.
So the more people we can get to look at that and talk about that,
the more-- the more hopeful we are that that can be a thing.
Rice: Not--not speaking to just, like, what's gonna happen in "Act 2," you know,
'cause that's how we've all been thinking about it for a long time, but speaking of, like,
what is this game?
Spafford: Looking at the full-- the full picture now it's done.
Other than that, we're just trying to, you know, beg, borrow, and steal every bit of coverage we can.
Rice: We were able to get a European press tour on zero dollars.
Schafer: I...w-well... Rice: So that's good.
Schafer: We're not paying anything for that?
Rice: Um, we are paying for three days of a B&B, but they're paying for all of our flights
and our B&B while we're there, so...
Um, I think it's all pretty set now.
So, um, flights and hotels and everything is in there.
There'll be-- basically we get to UK first for the first weekend,
and then the Monday after that we're doing, like, a bunch of press at Media Molecule.
Um, and we'll have Eurogamer, Edge, and The Guardian, uh, all that day in their offices.
And then, yeah, we have the talk in Vyborg with Peter and Ray.
[Music] Spafford: We should pick a day for having press around as well,
and then we can start organizing them.
[Music] Schafer: So what do you think so far, Marty?
Sliva: I think it's awesome.
Schafer: Give us your, um, full review now.
Sliva: Just verbatim, and then you guys can write it down.
Schafer: We need to know the score before we decide whether -you're leaving the room. Sliva: Yeah, okay.
Schafer: That's just a common-- Sliva: That's--that's happened-- That's happened before with other publishers, so--
Schafer: Really? They're, like... Rice: Oh, God.
Sliva: I think it's mostly like, like, "You can do an exclusive, but what's the score,"
you know what I mean? It's like, well, I'm not gonna do that, then.
Uh, everyone always says, like, "Oh, this is gonna be the adventure game
that gets people to play adventure games who haven't played adventure games."
Like, you--is that bullshit to you?
Like, is that-- is that necessary?
Do you think adventure games need that, -or do you think it's-- Schafer: I've always been--
I've always been interested in it, because it always seemed like
with adventure games that we were trying to get beyond the-- the limited audience
of people currently playing--playing games.
Not that they're limited, but there-- there was a, back in the '90s,
a small group of the culture at large that was playing games at all.
And it seemed like there are all these people who weren't playing games and they're like, hey,
I think you would like a game that, well, it's about story, where you don't have to worry about getting shot in the head,
and, like, you could play at your own pace and it involved themes that weren't
being covered in games, you know.
So we always, you know, we always, you know...
People would tell us, like, "This is the only game that my girlfriend will play with me."
And it was--that was always the story.
Like, there's all these people out there who, you know, why aren't they playing games?
And I think this is the game they would like.
But, um, you know, it's always been hard to reach those people, and, um, and make them feel like they would like--
You know, they think of themselves as someone who would not play video games.
It's hard to get past that identity problem, almost.
Sliva: Totally. Schafer: So I do think about it, but I don't think it's necessary.
Like, I think it's good enough to make a game that people--
and that's what this Kickstarter is all about.
Like, there are these people who said, "We like adventure games just the way they are."
And they don't need to completely revolutionize with--with how they interact.
They don't need to be a different genre.
They just, "We like the old adventure games and we wanna play another one."
And knowing they were out there and we were making the game for them, uh,
is what made it special this time around.
Rice: There's always been, like, conversation coming up here and there about how we're gonna give backers the codes,
or if we're gonna give them early access to the game or anything like that.
And I feel like it's never been, like, fully talked about and decided upon.
Schafer: I was--I wanted to give it just the--the day before, -the 24 hours before. Rice: Yeah.
Spafford: Yeah, if it's possible without too much mess, then I think that people will really appreciate it.
And in fact, we've set the embargo for press for the same time
as the backers getting their keys so that, you know, everyone's getting
their thing at the same time.
Offscreen: Yeah, 'cause the embargo thing was such an issue last time.
Spafford: I think there is all kinds of emotions about that.
Rice: Tim, did you hear that? Schafer: What?
Rice: "Digital Trends" posted an article, "Why We're Breaking the 'Broken Age' Embargo."
Schafer: Tell 'em maybe he didn't agree to anything, but he knows he's bein' a shit.
Bailey: I was looking over all of our news broadcasts, and basically all the exposure went out
when the backers got it, like, two weeks ago.
Spafford: I think that whole situation probably should have been done a bit differently.
I think we learned a lot from that, by the sounds of things, or at least I hope so.
And I've certainly watched that episode and--and thought, "Okay, we need to not do that."
Yeah, so, it--today is Friday.
Uh, on Sunday night, we're gonna send out backer keys to people, which is pretty exciting.
Um, 24 hours later, the game will unlock on Steam and be pushed out, uh, around the world
onto however many millions of platforms that we're doing.
Um, so by Tuesday, uh, morning when we all come into the office,
the game will be out, everyone will be playing, no one will have any problems, everything will be fine,
and everyone will be having a good time.
That's--that's the gist of it.

Hansen: Yeah, don't say that.
Rice: It's all gonna be perfect.
Hansen: It--it may not be perfect.

All right.
Let's put out the Kickstarter update?
Spafford: Let's do it.

Yo, yo, yo, yo, yo.
Hi, everybody.

Awesome, awesome.
Okay. Hi, everybody.
Uh, today I've been very preoccupied 'cause "Broken Age" is in the hands of our backers

Yeah!

Schafer: Okay.
Let's go to the forum, shall we?
"Spoiler: Need hint urgently." Ah! Ah!

Right?
Where's the general...
"Let's talk about how much we love the game" thread?
Let's see.
Discussion and feedback.
"I finished this morning.

That's it.
"Everything about 'Act 2' has improved the game dramatically.
The puzzles are a lot more detailed.
Required me to pull out a notepad." Yay.
That's nice. I'm glad it makes-- I get excited when I pull out a notepad.
"I liked 'Act 1,' but it was a little linear.
'Act 2' is perfect.
And to Tim and everyone at Double Fine, I really appreciate you and what you've done so much."
Well, that's nice.
Ah! The game's out.
I mean, it really comes out tomorrow, or midnight tonight.
But it's out, the review embargo is lifted, we got a 9.2 from "Game Informer,"
and it should be good for launch, official launch day tomorrow,
where it'll be out on all platforms and everywhere.
Um, so now we just sit around and read reviews and pretend we don't care about 'em.
That's the...regular thing.
I'm gonna sit there, like, all night just waiting for them to come in.
You see one, you're like, "Oh, that-- that was awesome! I'm gonna read one more!
Oh, that was bad, I'm not gonna-- not gonna read any m--
Oh, that one was nice!" And then it all evens out.
I just was reading, like, two different reviews, one talking about being too hard
and one being, it's too easy.
And, uh, you know, that just seems to be the way with those games.
They're just, like, um...
people--people react strongly and very subjectively and, um...I don't know.
Like, I feel like it takes years, almost, for people to really decide
how they feel about these games.
So 10 years from now we'll find out if it was any good.
Offscreen: It seems a bit strange that there's review scores for "Act 1," "Act 2--"
And the whole thing.
Schafer: Yeah, it's a mess... it's a mess.
Never split your game in half.
Rice: By the way, there's a lot of people talking about it, so that's good.
Um, and tomorrow we're partying, and I think I sent an invite out to everybody.

Um...it's--it's weird because it just happened to time out--
it happened to coincide with a weird phase of the Internet where everyone's super angry all the time and it just, like--
it was hard to be that open and transparent and give everybody--
It's like we opened up a little tray of, you know, bludgeoning instruments so that--
for people could beat us up with.
And then people picked 'em up and just beat us up with them.
And we're like, huh, that was an interesting experiment.
We probably shouldn't have given all those weapons to all the people who are mad.
But, um, if that had not erupted at that moment, you know, maybe I would've thought--
'Cause at the beginning, the transparency was nothing but, like,
um, hugs and, uh, high-fives all around.
Like, everybody at our-- you know, our PAX meetups, like, that was our community experience,
was everyone just telling us how much they were excited about the game
and how much they loved us and everything.
And then when we announced the change in the schedule, just all that-- just people just--
it seemed like there was a big crowd of people just ready to-- just really super mad.
And if you Google, like, um, "'Broken Age,' broken promises" on the Internet-- which I do every night--
if you Google that, you'll see all these angry articles.
Not just from, like, random people on Twitter, but, like, these journalists who are like,
"They really let everybody down with this and they should really be sorry."
And, um...
and here we are at the end and we're shipping the game and it took a long time,

Uh...and I want to mail all those people individually and be like,

I feel like...

But we made it, like, twice as much, almost, as we got in, or more.
And so, um, we will just about make that back.
And the biggest change is that we don't need the publishers anymore, 100%.
You know, it used to be, like, there was no money in the world outside of publishers.
And I think crowdfunding's here to stay.
I think it's, um, hopefully gonna grow.
And in my dream-- my dream world, it would be big enough to fund AAA games
and it would be the way that we fund all games going forward.
